Evidence from the Documents:

Uses the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt. (1 point)

OR

Supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least four documents. (2 points)

To earn one point, the response must accurately describe—rather than simply quote—the content from at least three of the documents to address the topic of the First World War and the relationships between Europeans and colonized peoples.

Example:

(Document 2) “Officer Kalyan Mukerji’s letter to a friend in India shows that the experience of the war has changed his views of England so that now he sees English-style nationalism as a bad thing.” (describes the document accurately, and thus is credited as addressing the topic, but does not explicitly tie the description to an argument in response to the prompt)

OR

To earn two points, the response must accurately describe—rather than simply quote—the content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content from the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.

Example:

(Document 1): “John Chilembwe’s letter to the Nyasaland Times shows that Europeans’ need for African recruits has changed the relationship between colonizers and colonial peoples because the British in Nyasaland now have to appeal to Africans’ sense of duty and patriotism. But, after seeing how Europeans have treated their colonial subjects in peacetime, Africans aren’t buying it.” (Connects the contents of the document to an argument about the ways in which the experience of the First World War changed the relationships between Europeans and colonized peoples.)

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

Example:

“The peace treaties that ended the war left the British and French empires untouched and actually expanded them through the Mandate system.” (provides a piece of evidence not in the documents relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt)

Sourcing: For at least two documents, explains how or why the document’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument. (1 point)

To earn this point, the response must explain—rather than simply identify—how or why the document’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.

Examples:

(Document 3): “Part of the French government’s purpose in printing this postcard may have been to reassure the French population that African troops serving in France can be friendly and trustworthy. So even though the card shows Africans and French civilians sitting next to each other and smiling, it probably indicates that ordinary French people continued to be biased against Africans, even those fighting for their country.” (provides sourcing regarding the purpose of the postcard relevant to an argument addressing the prompt)

(Document 4): “Even though someone writing a private letter to his family can be expected to share their honest opinion of a situation, this was not always the case with soldiers’ letter during the war. The reason for that was that soldiers knew that government censors often read their letters and could decide not to deliver them if they thought they revealed something secret or could be bad for people’s morale. For example, Behari Lal’s letter says that what he is writing “is not a hundredth part” of what is on his mind, suggesting that his experiences were actually much worse than he reveals in the letter.”(provides sourcing regarding the audience of the government reportrelevant to an argument addressing the prompt)

Task A: Identify ONE specific way in which the portrayal of the figures in the image reflects the political message presented in the painting.

Some examples that would earn credit include:

· The Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan is shown as the figure in the center of the image with a halo of light around his head, which most likely represents his great power.

· The image shows the European representatives at the bottom of the painting, which implies that they are less important than the Mughal emperor. This shows the intended message of the painting in praising the power and superiority of the Mughal emperor.

· All of the people in the image, including the Europeans, are facing Emperor Shah Jahan. All of them are showing respect, often with their hands or arms showing praise or pleading, which shows that the emperor is the most powerful, respected, and praised person in the image.

Task B: Identify ONE way in which the image reflects the relations between the Mughal Empire and other states during the period circa 1550–1650.

Some examples that would earn credit include:

· The image shows that the Mughal Empire under Shah Jahan has become very rich and powerful because people from different backgrounds and regions, including Europeans, all come to pay their respects and bear gifts for the ruler.

· The image shows that European merchants or representatives are not very important in India or Asia in this period because the European representatives are at the bottom of the image farthest from the emperor.

· The image shows that the Mughal Empire considers itself to be very powerful and wealthy because the emperor and his court members are all dressed in fine clothing, the architecture depicted in the image is richly adorned and elaborate, and the image itself is finely executed and ornate.

Task C: Explain ONE reason that the political relations portrayed in the image changed in the period circa 1650–1850.

Some examples that would earn credit include:

Task A: Describe ONE feature of nationalism in the period 1750–1900.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Some examples that would earn credit include:

· Nationalism was an ideology that governments used to unify people within their territories.

· Nationalism was the idea that certain communities were united by factors such as language, territorial boundaries, and a shared history, even if they also had many differences among them.

· Nationalism was an ideological movement that tried to provide an identity to people based on commonalities in language, religion, and ethnic origins.

Task B: Explain ONE political development in the period 1750–1900 that helped spread nationalism.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Some examples that would earn credit include:

· The French Revolution helped spread nationalism across Europe in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries because of the mass publication of literature from Enlightenment philosophes and because of the conquests of Napoleon’s armies.

· European colonialism in the Americas helped spread nationalism in those regions because many members of the local elite were exposed to nationalist ideas during the many conflicts between European states that took place in the Americas, like the Seven Years’ War.

· Resistance to imperial rule in Europe and other world regions, like the Greek rebellion against the Ottoman Empire, led to the spread of nationalism because people used the concept of national identity and oppression as a way of galvanizing opposition to imperial authorities.

Task C: Identify ONE instance in the period 1750–1900 in which nationalism was used to create a new state.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Some examples that would earn credit include:

· Nationalism was used to create Italy in the late nineteenth century.

· The Prussian government under Otto von Bismarck used nationalism to create a united Germany in 1871.

· Simón Bolívar used nationalist ideas to establish independent republics in Latin America in the early nineteenth century.

VR254886_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – COMPLEXITY
VR254886_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

· Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

· Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of states practicing religious tolerance in the period 1450-1750.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating complex understanding might include:

· Explaining varying degrees of state tolerance or intolerance vis-à-vis various religious groups, for example different treatment of dhimmi and non-dhimmi groups in Islam; whether Hindus could or could not be considered dhimmi, different extent of toleration extended to various Protestant sects by different European states, etc. (Explains nuance and similarities and differences)

· Connecting to other time periods, such as comparison of the 1450-1750 practices with ideas and practices of religious toleration inspired by Enlightenment ideas and classical liberalism in the period circa 1750-1900 (Explains relevant and insightful connections)

· Qualifying or modifying an argument by examining the question of religious tolerance or lack of tolerance both as state policy and as social practice, for example comparing state policies with individual or group acts of intolerance (such as witchcraft accusations, anti-Semitism, etc.) or tolerance (such as Sufi practices, Christian missionaries serving as preservers of native cultures, etc.). VR260035_rubric_category_6.ti: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – COMPLEXITY
VR260035_rubric_category_6.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

· Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

· Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Effectively using seven documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of how Mongol cultural practices changed in response to Mongol interactions with conquered peoples in the period circa 1200–1350.
o.af:
Examples of demonstrating complex understanding might include:

· Recognizing that some documents corroborate, qualify, and/or modify the overall argument, for example, by consistently demonstrating awareness of political, economic, and cultural factors that led the Mongols to adopt or reject foreign traditions (Corroborates, qualifies or modifies an argument by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence)

· Explaining the nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple factors or by considering diverse or alternative perspectives or evidence, such as constructing an argument that explains how the Mongols might have adopted some cultural traditions from sedentary societies but retained many of their core cultural traditions and borrowed as much if not more from other nomadic peoples (Explains nuance)

· Connecting to other time periods by illustrating specific similarities and differences between the cultural influences of conquered peoples on the Mongols compared to the cultural influences of conquered peoples on other societies in the Early Modern or Modern periods (Explains relevant and insightful connections)

The Scotsman may have had fears of future conflict between Russia and the neighboring Qing."

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

· [Document 5]: “Because his travel account is addressed to an Ottoman audience, Evliya Chelebi’s description may have been intended as a warning to Ottoman authorities about the lawlessness existing in the remote regions of the empire.”

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

· Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

· Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which globalization affected culture during the period since circa 1950.

(Corroborates an argument, considers both causes and effects)

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

o.d: The response does not use at least one additional piece of specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the extent to which enslaved Africans or their descendants preserved their African cultures in American colonial societies during the period circa 1500–1900.
o.af:
Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

  • Examples of African-influenced syncretic religions that developed in the Americas – Haitian vodun, Brazilian candomblé, Cuban santeria, etc.

  • Events or figures from the Haitian revolution relevant to the process of abolishing slavery or preserving African culture in Saint-Domingue / Haiti.

  • Events or historical figures relevant to the process of limiting or abolishing slavery in the Atlantic World, e.g. the British Slave Trade Act of 1807, the prohibition and subsequent reinstatement of slavery in the French empire during the French revolutionary period, etc.

  • Examples of Africans in the Americas embracing Christianity, e.g. Afro-American saints or other religious figures, such as Saint Martin of Porres.

  • Examples of maroon communities other than those mentioned in the documents – Brazilian quilombos such as Palmares, Jamaican maroon settlements.

  • Other slave revolts in the Americas, e.g. 1835 Malê Revolt in Brazil, Nat Turner’s 1831 rebellion in Virginia.

  • Examples of creolized languages in the Americas preserving significant elements from African languages, e.g. Gullah in colonial North America, Garifuna language in Belize, etc.

Example of evidence beyond the documents relevant to an argument about the prompt:

  • “The Haitian Revolution, led by Toussaint L’Ouverture, is one of the best examples of enslaved Africans rejecting colonial culture and politics, and establishing their own state.” (Provides a piece of evidence not in the documents relevant to an argument about the prompt)

  • “Other American syncretic religious that developed from the mixture of African beliefs in spirits and Christian religious teachings include Haitian vodun.” (Provides a piece of evidence not in the documents relevant to an argument about the prompt)

o.af:

  • [Document 2]: “The author’s advice to slave holders seems to be based on his experience living and preaching in Brazil. As such, his account provides credible evidence that enslaved Afro-Brazilians sought opportunities to continue to practice their traditional culture as ‘their only relief in their slavery.’” (Connects the point-of-view of the author to an argument about the persistence and acceptance of African cultural practices in colonial Brazilian society)

  • [Document 3]: “The author’s purpose is to ensure the continued autonomy of his community and to keep both White landowners and the colonial government from interfering in the affairs of the community. To that effect, he emphasizes the community’s devotion to the Virgin of Guadalupe.” (Connects the purpose of the document to an argument about a runaway community of formerly enslaved people of African descent seeking to preserve their cultural and political autonomy in colonial Mexico)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the historical situation of a source:

  • [Document 6]: “The celebrations depicted in the painting represent a scene of cultural syncretism in which a Christian festival becomes assimilated and culturally reimagined through the cultural and religious practices of the Afro-Cuban people.” (Connects the historical situation of the document to an argument about the emergence and/ or acceptance of syncretic religious practices among Afro-Cuban people in the nineteenth century.)

Example of an acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience of a source:

  • [Document 4]: “Published in 1796, when the Haitian revolution was well underway, Steadman’s book may have found an audience in Britain that was already steeped in debates about the sustainability of Atlantic-world slavery and Enlightenment-inspired abolitionist ideas.” (Connects the intended audience of the document to an argument about how the persistence of African cultural traditions in the Americas intersected with debates in Europe about the economic and moral sustainability of Atlantic-world slavery).

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

For example, a response may explore the ways in attitudes to the issue of maintaining African culture were influenced by variables such as social class, gender, extent of religious devotion, enslaved versus free, etc. For example, a response may argue that despite being a priest, the author of Document 2 is taking a practical view on the need to allow enslaved Brazilians to continue to practice some non-Christian aspects of their culture, or that, in Document 4, the [presumably free] Black soldiers’ views on colonial hierarchies are clearly different from those of the enslaved Black rebels, or that, in Documents 6 and 7, there is evidence that both wealthy and poor Afro-Cubans maintained aspects of their African culture, even though the wealthy were more likely to do so while adopting behaviors that emphasized their desire to blend into colonial society (through the wearing of European-style clothing or claiming to be “pure Catholics.”) (Explains nuance)

VR734102_rubric_category_5.ti: Part D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – COMPLEXITY
VR734102_rubric_category_5.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

  • A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

  • Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

  • Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

  • Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

  • Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways that might include:

  • Explaining how multiple pieces of specific and relevant evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

  • Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

o.d:
The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the extent to which an individual, group, or movement in the mid- to late twentieth century successfully challenged existing power structures during this period.
